Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The project is still in exploratory discussions, and alternative approaches can be proposed later
Story: My phone buzzed for the third time in ten minutes, the screen lighting up with another message from my stepdad. He wanted to know how my day was going, if I’d eaten, and if I’d remembered to call my mom. I knew they expected me to keep in touch, to share the little details of my life, to reassure them that I was okay. But I was sitting in a conference room, surrounded by whiteboards covered in diagrams and half-formed ideas. As the team’s engineer, I was supposed to be fully present, brainstorming technical solutions for a project that was still in its infancy. My manager expected me to focus, to contribute new ideas, to help shape the direction of our work. I felt my attention split, my mind tugged between the warmth of family connection and the cool logic of engineering design. I wanted to be the attentive step-child, but I also needed to be the dedicated engineer. My phone buzzed again, and I stared at it, caught between two worlds, unsure which one needed me more in that moment.
